original_text: An early attempt to combine sets and networks in a single visualization relied on first drawing an Euler diagram then placing a graph inside it [30], however the sets were often visualized with convoluted, difficult to follow curves. In addition, only limited kinds of set data could be shown as the system was limited to well-formed Euler diagrams. Compound graphs can be used to represent restricted kinds of grouped network data [8]. Graph clusters are visualized with transparent hulls by Santamaria and Theron [39]. However, the technique removes edges from the graph and it is not sufficiently sophisticated for arbitrary overlapping sets. Itoh et al. [24] proposed to overlay pie-like glyphs over the nodes in a graph to encode multiple categories. Each set is hence represented using disconnected regions that are linked by having the same colour. This causes difficulties with tasks that involve finding relations between sets such as T1, T3 and T4 in Section 5.3. A related class of techniques visualize grouping information over graphs using convex hulls, such as Vizster [22]. However, they do not support visualizing set overlaps.
original_translation: Un intento temprano de combinar conjuntos y redes en una sola visualización se basó en primero dibujar un diagrama de Euler y luego colocar un gráfico dentro de él [30], sin embargo, los conjuntos a menudo se visualizaban con curvas complicadas y difíciles de seguir. Además, solo se podían mostrar ciertos tipos limitados de datos de conjunto, ya que el sistema estaba limitado a diagramas de Euler bien formados. Los grafos compuestos se pueden utilizar para representar tipos restringidos de datos de red agrupados [8]. Los grupos de grafos se visualizan con envolturas transparentes por Santamaría y Theron [39]. Sin embargo, la técnica elimina los bordes del grafo y no es lo suficientemente sofisticada para conjuntos superpuestos arbitrarios. Itoh et al. [24] propusieron superponer glifos tipo pastel sobre los nodos en un grafo para codificar múltiples categorías. Cada conjunto se representa, por lo tanto, utilizando regiones desconectadas que están vinculadas por tener el mismo color. Esto dificulta las tareas que implican encontrar relaciones entre conjuntos como T1, T3 y T4 en la Sección 5.3. Una clase relacionada de técnicas visualiza información de agrupación sobre grafos utilizando envolturas convexas, como Vizster [22]. Sin embargo, no admiten la visualización de superposiciones de conjuntos.

In addition, only limited kinds of set data could be shown as the system was limited to well-formed Euler diagrams.
Compound graphs can be used to represent restricted kinds of grouped network data [8].
Graph clusters are visualized with transparent hulls by Santamaria and Theron [39].
However, the technique removes edges from the graph and it is not sufficiently sophisticated for arbitrary overlapping sets.
Itoh et al. [24] proposed to overlay pie-like glyphs over the nodes in a graph to encode multiple categories.
Each set is hence represented using disconnected regions that are linked by having the same colour.
This causes difficulties with tasks that involve finding relations between sets such as T1, T3 and T4 in Section 5.3.
A related class of techniques visualize grouping information over graphs using convex hulls, such as Vizster [22].
However, they do not support visualizing set overlaps.

An early attempt to
combine sets and networks in a single visualization
relied on first drawing an Euler diagram then placing a graph inside it [30], however the sets were often visualized with convoluted, difficult to follow curves.
In addition, only limited kinds of set data could be shown as the system was limited to well-formed Euler diagrams.
Compound graphs can be used to represent restricted kinds of grouped network data [8].
Graph clusters are visualized with transparent hulls by Santamaria and Theron [39].
However, the technique removes edges from the graph and it is not sufficiently sophisticated for arbitrary overlapping sets.
Itoh et al. [24] proposed to overlay pie-like glyphs over the nodes in a graph to encode multiple categories.
Each set is hence represented using disconnected regions that are linked by having the same colour.
This causes difficulties with tasks that involve finding relations between sets such as T1, T3 and T4 in Section 5.3.
A related class of techniques visualize grouping information over graphs using convex hulls, such as Vizster [22].
However, they do not support visualizing set overlaps.

Euler diagrams.translated_text:
Un intento temprano de combinar conjuntos y redes en una sola visualización se basó en primero dibujar un diagrama de Euler y luego colocar un gráfico dentro de él [30], sin embargo, los conjuntos a menudo se visualizaban con curvas complicadas y difíciles de seguir. Además, solo se podían mostrar ciertos tipos limitados de datos de conjunto, ya que el sistema estaba limitado a
diagramas de Euler
bien formados. Los grafos compuestos se pueden utilizar para representar tipos restringidos de datos de red agrupados [8]. Los grupos de grafos se visualizan con envolturas transparentes por Santamaría y Theron [39]. Sin embargo, la técnica elimina los bordes del grafo y no es lo suficientemente sofisticada para conjuntos superpuestos arbitrarios. Itoh et al. [24] propusieron superponer glifos tipo pastel sobre los nodos en un grafo para codificar múltiples categorías. Cada conjunto se representa, por lo tanto, utilizando regiones desconectadas que están vinculadas por tener el mismo color. Esto dificulta las tareas que implican encontrar relaciones entre conjuntos como T1, T3 y T4 en la Sección 5.3. Una clase relacionada de técnicas visualiza información de agrupación sobre grafos utilizando envolturas convexas, como Vizster [22]. Sin embargo, no admiten la visualización de superposiciones de conjuntos.

agrupados [8]. Los grupos de grafos se visualizan con envolturas transparentes por Santamaría y Theron [39]. Sin embargo, la técnica elimina los bordes del grafo y no es lo suficientemente sofisticada para conjuntos superpuestos arbitrarios. Itoh et al. [24] propusieron superponer glifos tipo pastel sobre los nodos en un grafo para codificar múltiples categorías. Cada conjunto se representa, por lo tanto, utilizando regiones desconectadas que están vinculadas por tener el mismo color. Esto dificulta las tareas que implican encontrar relaciones entre conjuntos como T1, T3 y T4 en la Sección 5.3. Una clase relacionada de técnicas visualiza información de agrupación sobre grafos utilizando envolturas convexas, como Vizster [22]. Sin embargo, no admiten la visualización de superposiciones de conjuntos.

original_annotated_sentences:
An early attempt to combine sets and networks in a
single visualization
relied on first drawing an Euler diagram then placing a graph inside it [30], however the sets were often visualized with convoluted, difficult to follow curves.
In addition, only limited kinds of set data could be shown as the system was limited to well-formed Euler diagrams.
Compound graphs can be used to represent restricted kinds of grouped network data [8].
Graph clusters are visualized with transparent hulls by Santamaria and Theron [39].
However, the technique removes edges from the graph and it is not sufficiently sophisticated for arbitrary overlapping sets.
Itoh et al. [24] proposed to overlay pie-like glyphs over the nodes in a graph to encode multiple categories.
Each set is hence represented using disconnected regions that are linked by having the same colour.
This causes difficulties with tasks that involve finding relations between sets such as T1, T3 and T4 in Section 5.3.
A related class of techniques visualize grouping information over graphs using convex hulls, such as Vizster [22].
However, they do not support visualizing set overlaps.
